column35: 2.4 How often do you use the following ways to get information about users?: I interact with the users before they use the software

column37: 2.4 How often do you use the following ways to get information about users?: I interact with the users when they are using the software (e.g., talk-aloud study)

column40: 2.4 How often do you use the following ways to get information about users?: Through direct feedback (e.g. via email, forums )
column41: 2.5 Try to remember a situation where you knew that involving users in development would be useful, but you could not involve them. Please describe the situation and what challenges you faced.
column42: 3.1 Does your company conduct experiments involving the users?:
column43: 3.2 Please describe a typical experiment you have seen or been involved in in your company, including the roles. (Skip this if you have not seen or been involved in any experiments.)
column44: To understand users' needs better, ...: data should always be collected because it might be needed later
column45: To understand users' needs better, ...: data should only be collected when there is a known need or assumption
column46: To understand users' needs better, ...: rich, detailed data about what users do is useful
column47: To understand users' needs better, ...: focused data on a specific user action or behaviour is useful
column48: To understand users' needs better, ...: users themselves must be actively involved in shaping the software
column49: To understand users' needs better, ...: we need to measure user behaviour to decide what the software should be like
column50: 4.1 How much do you agree with the following statements regarding notifying users about experiments? Please answer according to your personal beliefs.: Users do not need to know they are involved
column51: 4.1 How much do you agree with the following statements regarding notifying users about experiments? Please answer according to your personal beliefs.: If we collect personal information, users need to be notified
column52: 4.1 How much do you agree with the following statements regarding notifying users about experiments? Please answer according to your personal beliefs.: If no laws are being broken, users do not need to be notified
column53: 4.1 How much do you agree with the following statements regarding notifying users about experiments? Please answer according to your personal beliefs.: Users can be involved in an experiment without their knowledge if we let them know afterwards
column54: 4.1 How much do you agree with the following statements regarding notifying users about experiments? Please answer according to your personal beliefs.: Users should always be notified when they are being involved in an experiment
column55: 4.1 How much do you agree with the following statements regarding notifying users about experiments? Please answer according to your personal beliefs.: It is ok not to disclose all the experiment details to users involved
column56: 4.1 How much do you agree with the following statements regarding notifying users about experiments? Please answer according to your personal beliefs.: It is ok to trick the user if the validity of experiment results depend on it
column57: 4.2 How much do you agree with the following statements about involving users in experiments? Please answer according to your personal beliefs.: I cannot trust that the results will be correct
column58: 4.2 How much do you agree with the following statements about involving users in experiments? Please answer according to your personal beliefs.: Involving users in experiments is time-consuming
column59: 4.2 How much do you agree with the following statements about involving users in experiments? Please answer according to your personal beliefs.: My customer does not have the needed technical infrastructure
column60: 4.2 How much do you agree with the following statements about involving users in experiments? Please answer according to your personal beliefs.: Users would not like to be part of software experiments
column61: 4.2 How much do you agree with the following statements about involving users in experiments? Please answer according to your personal beliefs.: Users have to be convinced of the benefit before taking part
column62: 4.2 How much do you agree with the following statements about involving users in experiments? Please answer according to your personal beliefs.: Experiments give users false expectations
column63: 4.2 How much do you agree with the following statements about involving users in experiments? Please answer according to your personal beliefs.: Experiments reveal secrets about my customer's product strategy
column64: 5.1 How much do you agree with the following statements regarding benefits of experimentation? Please answer according to your personal beliefs.: Experiments would give me earlier feedback on how users respond to features
column65: 5.1 How much do you agree with the following statements regarding benefits of experimentation? Please answer according to your personal beliefs.: Experiments would give me an understanding of user value before releases
column66: 5.1 How much do you agree with the following statements regarding benefits of experimentation? Please answer according to your personal beliefs.: Experiments would mean that decisions are based on empirical evidence rather than opinions
column67: 5.1 How much do you agree with the following statements regarding benefits of experimentation? Please answer according to your personal beliefs.: Experiments would allow me to identify changes in user needs or market demand

column69: 5.2 In order to understand the users, my customer would be prepared to ...: create a user jury
column70: 5.2 In order to understand the users, my customer would be prepared to ...: join a user jury
column71: 5.2 In order to understand the users, my customer would be prepared to ...: spend work time to design and run experiments
column72: 5.2 In order to understand the users, my customer would be prepared to ...: invest into learning how to conduct systematic, hypothesis-based experiments
column73: 5.2 In order to understand the users, my customer would be prepared to ...: disseminate the experiment results and learnings in the organisation

column43: E.g. a/b studies via analytics, user interviews during prototyping/design, etc.
A/B testing, showing different content / content in different order per testing group
We use A/B testing and more advanced testing  actively.

column41: Now that we're rebuilding the adidas.com site, it's mindless to code some of the components that my experience says will only rarely be used by the end-user.  If I could even get a hold of their analytics, I could show that one of the buttons that'd take me a few days to build is not clicked by anyone in the past year (personal assumption). This would give me leverage to better optimize our development schedule by removing some legacy components when I could rationalize my beliefs with user feedback/analytics data.
column43: We'll create a new component to website and A/B test the results on sales/engagement/other metric.

column41: No such case so far. I work very close to the users (many of them work on the same floor as I and our team.
column43: skip

column41: Testing the discoverability of elements and services in the UI. Best feedback would be available on board a flight, but it is hard to observe users onboard directly or to get consent for remote monitoring because of privacy issues. Users can be invited to a test lab, but it is a different setting compared to being onboard an actual flight.
Some situation with very tight schedule.
column43: We recently made a PoC with real data and feedback from users.

column11: 90% HMH + 10% Veikkaus, HBO, VR, Nelonen, HUS, rex (internal)
column43: A typical case is about using A/B testing on real users. Many of our teams do that, but not all.

column41: The need was obvious, but client didn't have have direct contacts to users and time was very limited to come up first ui design.
I will always and every time make sure I will get the real end user involved. Always!
column43: Camoon! should I write here the whole User Centered design process. We got users invoved in all phases of the process, from the early fuzzy end until launching the service or product and while it is in markets and use. All the people who are involved in the process, will participate some how to the "experiments" what ever they are - Contextual user studies etc. with prototypes or existing product.

column74: the software has only internal users, i.e. not a consumer product

column41: Some ladders up in the management epics were written for a product idea that was not validated in any way. It did not only lack user validation. It also lacked validation from organisations substance and product's identity point of view. Oh, and the business goals and the product idea did not match.  Without user insight it was not possible to formulate any sensible next steps for development. Also challenging the idea was tough.  As the idea for the product was very vague it was not easy to pinpoint what kind of user data would be helpful.  In the process someone had already decided how the users would be involved in the process. But it did not quite fit to the current situation.  Team was mixed with experts from various companies and their poit of view and understanding of the situation did not match either. Thus it took ages to get user interview rolling.
column43: Prototypes tested with users.

column41: In my previous project we designed a slot machine game and wanted to test it with users, but it was really difficult, eventually impossible, to arrange a quick questionnaire among the players.  We were not allowed to interview them while they were playing or invite them to come and see the game on its development stage.
column43: Interviews and paper prototypes of the UI

column41: I was designing software for the end-users but I wasn't allowed to travel abroad to meet them. It was terrible to do guess design. With end-users I could have validated the hypotheses and remove things that weren't necessary for them.
column43: Let the users test the prototype and get the feedback from them

column41: Key steps in user organization's internal workflow and related technical integrations were unknown to us. We made a best guess as to what would be a sensible workflow and what integrations it would require, and shipped a product increment with that for testing. The customer was very happy and provided relatively minor additional feature requests for next iteration.
column43: A complexity is observed in a workflow. This results in a hypothesis in how it could be simplified, to improve the user's experience. The hypothesis is discussed, with drawn sketches in case of UI issues, with users. When a satisfactory design is identified, a simple implementation with pre-defined analytics hooks is done and deployed. After deployment feedback from pilot users is gathered and compared with the analytics data. Based on both outcomes the feature is either left permanently in, or removed or refactored.

column41: A huge time pressure:  1. I know the users' needs based on their feedback (subcontractors need to know a summary of their monthly hours in order to bill the same hours themselves).  2. However, implementing a solution (= sending them an email summary at the end of the month, i.e. definitely not the perfect solution) takes 4 hours, which are available right now, today. It won't solve things but improve them.   => Implementation with no users involved and let's see what the feedback will be.

column20: Documentation (API documentation, usage guidelines), metrics, analytics.

column41: At a client i wasn't allowed to gather users because of various reasons. They didn't have a process of how to get in touch with users either. This made it extremely hard for me/us to get users involved. In the end i interviewed friends/relatives/acquaintances/colleagues.

column43: Running through some scenario with real users and observing results. Mostly UX designers involved.

column20: I assumed testing and the activities after release refer to usability testing and feedback
column41: I wanted users to test a specific form with real data. However due to reasons deriving from the software's backend, I had to wait for the users to fill in another form and wait for the form to be processed before they could use the one that had to be tested. In some cases it took a month before a user could test what I wanted them to.
column43: Usability tests: following a software's use either by visiting the users' premises, or by screen sharing.  Also displaying low-fidelity or high-fidelity prototypes to users and asking them to complete tasks.  Data is also monitored to measure the effect of implemented changes in software.

column20: project management, budget, relase plans etc

column43: We launched live test web site for playing around with a math editor that might be embedded into digital matriculation examination system.
We ship software to see if the users can get the job done, then improve with help of the findings and feedback.

We've done several feature experiments, published them to the production and then followed their take-up rate. We've also done many sort of "growth hacking" experiments within our service and we are also currently in the middle of a big A-B test that will have a big impact on our future roadmap. Also we are constantly experimenting with our ways of working and regularly develop new methods to tackle problems we encounter in managing our error handling, work balance, task flow and whatnot.
Implement feature only on 1 platform and some subset. Then collect data and later devide whether to implement on other platforms and/or expand functionality.
column74: Feedback from users who are both users and employees is valued.

column43: UI A/B testing, interviews with prototypes/screenshots
Build a minimal app, release to limited set of users, collect feedback
piloting with restricted user base for new feature

column41: We wanted to interview Chinese passengers coming to Helsinki Airport, but even with an interpreter with us, it's tricky to get them talking.  Going to the terminal to interview passengers is tricky, because of needed permits and we always need someone to escort us during the visit.
column43: We've been trying out guidance concepts in live situations by producing the needed data ourselves by hand. Then we've observed how they've worked in action before coding anything.  It's really difficult to get quantitative data about the success of these experiments, as there is currently nothing for the passengers to interact with that could be tracked. So far, we've relied on qualitative short interviews and filming the tests.
Certain features are only released to a subset of users. Mostly done for testing/assurance purposes, but user feedbackâ€”if anyâ€”is also considered.

column41: We wrote software for common Finnish people but got inspective testing only from product owners and by other project members. We should have used more people in testing that are not familiar with concept and software we were building.  For the future we told to customer that at least tester not familiar for concept should be hired to the next same kind of project.
column43: Designers go and monitor how end users do they work that the software under design is supposed to be helpful.  Analytics is collected from users behaviour e.g. every page view and button press events and some analysis is done with this data.
A/B-test that involves different users using slightly different versions of the software service.

Our UX designers typically present initial drafts of the User Interface to actual users, and test them out before any code is written. Similarly, users are often involved throughout the development to test ready software and give feedback about it.
